properties.description: Posted by Shannonor751/755 South 4th Street, Philadelphia, PA(From Daily Candy) June 9, 2006 If These Thighs Could Talk Waist (to Hips): Are you comfortable? Cause I’m swimmin’. Hips: Hell, no! We’re choking in here! Thighs (to all): Quit your bitching. We lost circulation an hour ago. And so the struggle for a great-fitting pair of jeans continues. Thank heavens, then, for Larnell Baldwin, of Baldwin’s Leather and Fabrics. He’ll make those jeans fit like a glove as he alters yokes, inseams, waistbands, and hems. He’ll take those Sass & Bides, J Brands, or Levi’s and transform them into jeans you can live — and even breathe — in. And it’ll cost you only 0, max. So wearing your favorite pair of jeans no longer has to give your body the blues … Literally and figuratively speaking. Baldwin’s Leather and Fabrics, 751/755 South 4th Street (215-627-7668).

properties.name: Bar Ferdinand
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor1030 North Second Street, philadelphia, PA(from Daily Candy) July 14, 2006 Take Me Out Ferdinands in History: Archduke Ferdinand: Gets assassinated. Starts war. Franz Ferdinand: Skinny ties and disco punk. Now? A third Ferdinand rolls onto the scene. Fashion designer-turned-interior decorator Owen Kamihira’s first solo culinary venture, Bar Ferdinand, is a NoLibs tapas restaurant and wine bar modeled in the spirit of old-world Espana. Blake Joffe (Alma de Cuba, El Vez) is in the kitchen; Philly artist Joe Brenman’s mosaics of famous matadors and pastoral Spain line the walls. Even the vaulted ceiling — painted gold with a candlelit chandelier — is a throwback to Moorish times. Plates, which range in price from to , include crab-and-white-asparagus flan; charred watermelon with Serrano ham and tarragon; and smoked trout with potato, chives, piquillo peppers, and shallots. Showin’ love for cash-poor party animals: The place is open seven days til 2 a.m. and offers wine-of-the-week specials and draft beer, including Alhambra, a Spanish lager exclusive to Ferdie’s. Now that’s one for the history books. Bar Ferdinand, 1030 North Second Street (215-923-1313 or barferdinand.com).

properties.name: Bronx bar
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor4476 Second Ave., Detroit, MIBest jukebox The Bronx Bar 4476 Second Ave., Detroit 313-832-8464 Something strange happened last winter. The Bronx Bar, which has been on the corner of Second and Prentis for as long as anyone can remember, quietly went from being an underappreciated dive bar that kept odd hours to being a positively hip, dark-as-a-mine shaft watering hole that keeps wee-hours hours. Most important, though, are two jukeboxes that will endear themselves to hardened music freaks. Early ’80s post-punk, classic hip hop, deep soul, indie-rock favorites, and a slew of Detroit bands make up a dumbfounding roster of lovable non-hits. You might spend more on the jukebox than on drinks.

properties.name: Cantina El Caballito
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor 1651 East Passyunk Avenue, Philadelphia, PA(From Daily Candy) May 31, 2006 Run for the Border! (or the Bathroom) Too salty. Too sweet. Waaaay too watered down. For the love of Cinco de Mayo and fishbowl glasses everywhere, can somebody please make us a decent margarita? Dave Frank and Stephen Simons, co-owners of South Philly comfort pub Royal Tavern, have the perfect solution. Or better yet, the perfect recipe. With 32 types of primo tequila in house, including top-shelf anejos, the bartenders at the brand-new Cantina El Caballito have mastered the art of margarita making. They’ve got traditional lime, of course, but we recommend putting on your party-girl hat and downing a prickly pear, strawberry, or pomegranate. Order a pitcher for your friends and sit on the outdoor patio among candles and punched tin lamps. If the buzz starts to catch you, order one of chef Miguel Aguilar’s (of Alma de Cuba fame) kicked-up tacos or signature entrees. Eat. Drink. ¡Fiesta! (Forever!) Hungover! Cantina El Caballito, 1651 East Passyunk Avenue (215-755-3550).

properties.name: Dee's Hideaway
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor51st and Hadfield sts., philadelphia, paDee\'s Hideaway 51st and Hadfield sts. Bar/Pub, West Philadelphia/University City Turning 21 means gettin\' down at almost any bar in town. Ordering a drink at Dee\'s Hideaway in West Philly, however, means waiting till your 30th birthday. Bartender Sissie Savage cards everyone who walks in, and while she won\'t serve alcohol to twentysomethings, over-21s can still hang out, sip Shirley Temples and study their imbibing elders. Wednesday is "Dollar Wheel Day" at Hideway; from 3 to 7 p.m., every drink ordered buys patrons a chance to spin a numbered wheel. Savage, also known as "Vanna Black," presides over the wheel, handing out dollar-store prizes and collecting extra tips for the bartender if the spinner lands on the number 13. No phone. * Average entree under 0 * Late-night dining * Liquor license * Smoking Allowed

properties.name: Denise's Soul Food/Carribean Style lunch truck
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor (from chowhound.com) Woah - based on previous Chowhound recommendations, I just walked across Philly to try Denise\'s Soul Food/Carribean Style lunch truck and it was awesome. Location: Market and 30th just to the left of the train station (with your back to the Schuylkill). Had the "large" fried chicken for .50. Small was less and unless you\'re feeding two people, I\'d strongly recommend sticking with a small. Large was 2 entire thigh/legs and 2 heaping servings of sides. The chicken was piping hot, tender, with a crispy coating, covered with hot sauce (optional) comparable to tabasco in terms of flavor and bite. The crust had no extra salt, allowing the flavor of the chicken and the batter to shine through. The true test of perfect fried chicken -- the skin and coating were still crispy after the whole meal was done. Sides: Tried the green beans which were fresh, hot, a bit salty but not overly so, and had a touch of onions I believe. Yum. Also had the candied yams -- perfectly soft but not mushy, sweet but not too much so. Overall - sides were done right. The chicken was the highlight of the meal though and this was the best fried chicken (if not best chicken period) I\'ve had in recent memory, and that includes several trips from San Francisco to the East Coast passing through the Deep South, so take that! Denises\' will do ya right! Almost forgot to mention -- I didn\'t order it, but for you get 32oz of homemade ice-tea in a plastic tub. Other menu items include fried fish, jerk chicken, and a variety of sides, but they\'ll all have to wait because I\'m still full from the chicken. Other: No atmosphere to speak of, but remember this is a lunch truck. Take your meal into the beautiful 30th street train station and grab a seat.

properties.name: Distinguished Fabrics
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor770/772 South 4th Street, Philadelphia, PA(From Daily Candy) June 26, 2006 Sole Mate Shoes are like lovers. You spend so much time breaking them in, molding them to your needs, then one day you wake up and realize they’re no longer what you fell in love with. Don’t chuck them just yet. All they need is a good repurposing. In about one week, Yahya at Distinguished Fabrics, a favorite tailor and fabric merchandiser of the Philly elite, can replace the upper of a dated leather shoe for a whole new look. Go for a custom tweed, textured fabric, or Gucci logo — whatever suits your style. For much less than it would cost you and your bunions to break in a new pair, you’ll have something that feels comfortably familiar yet refreshingly new. Talk about a match made in heaven. Distinguished Fabrics, 770/772 South 4th Street (215-627-6380).

properties.name: El Fuego
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor 723 Walnut St., Philadelphia, PAEl Fuego has the best burritos in the city. They are indeed Cali-Mex, and is ironically either owned or at least staffed by a number of Argentineans (they hang Argentina flags and El Fuego was mobbed by Argies for their World Cup matches). All the burritos are .25 but I highly recommend the vegetarian burrito over the meat varieties since it comes with guac, which is otherwise an extra .75. The salsas are fresh and tasty, the guac is great, and the beans are well-prepared. Good tortillas...everything\'s well-prepared. As an added bonus, they have a large flat-screen TV on the wall that\'s almost always showing Fox Soccer Channel or GolTV.

properties.name: Kiki Berlin's Damaged Goods Pin-Up Emporium, at Funhouse Antiques and Collectibles
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor 720 South Fifth Street, Philadelphia, PA[from Daily Candy] What’s Your Damage? You’ve been known to play Agent Provocateur. And you can definitely keep Victoria’s Secrets. So you’ll want to make room in your underwear drawer for something from burlesque queen Kiki Berlin’s Damaged Goods Pin-Up Emporium. The tiny shop-within-a-shop specializes in vintage and retro lingerie — everything from garters and girdles to bustiers and stockings. Not your average granny panties, the steamy styles are as classic as the grand dames that inspired them: Marilyn, Rita, and, of course, Betty. Would-be calendar girls can purchase bullet bras for under work clothes, but if you’re terrified of the Twin Peaks look, Kiki also sells old stag mags, pinup art, jewelry, scarves, go-go boots, and opera gloves. But honestly, it’s probably best if you just let go of your inhibitions. Especially if you ever plan to party in Hollywood with Frederick. Damaged Goods Pin-Up Emporium, at Funhouse Antiques and Collectibles, 720 South Fifth Street (215-238-8873).

properties.name: Liberty Boards
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor 30 South 7th Street, Philadelphia, PA(from Daily Candy) August 2, 2006 Big Tees Cute T-shirts and good beer: They’ve got a lot in common. They make tough days easier, go great with most foods, and you can always use another. Artist Julie Goldstein understands your thirst for just the right tee — and is doing her best to satisfy it with her appropriately named line, Perfect. Since the versatile and wearable shirts and tanks feature one-of-a-kind prints, no small amount of work goes into each one. Goldstein spends anywhere from eight hours to two weeks creating an original woodcut, which is then used to apply the print — either to the individual top or a patch that is later sewn on. The images come directly from her own observations, personal memories, and portrayals of female strength and independence. So not only are her shirts wearable, they actually mean something. All the more reason to order up another round. Available at Liberty Boards, 30 South 7th Street (215-238-9162 or libertyboardriders.com).

properties.name: Lucky Strike Lanes
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor 1336 Chestnut Street, Philadelphia, PA(from Daily Candy) June 15, 2006 Super Bowl Potbellies, back hair, New Jersey. Just a few things that come to mind when one thinks of bowling. Oh, and that scene from Kingpin, when Bill Murray’s comb-over is flyin’ all wild as he runs down the lane. Well, you’d better readjust your perceptions, because bowling just got all classed up. No more beer-swilling dirty old men and no more rival high school gangs smoking reefer in the parking lot — not, at least, at Lucky Strike, the famed L.A. bowling lounge making its Philly debut. With two stories, 24 lanes, six pool tables, a sports bar, and the city’s largest roof deck (come fall), the place is downright swanky. And forget about corn dogs; Lucky Strike’s bistro menu includes grilled tomato, basil and mozzarella sandwiches, and a turkey club with applewood-smoked bacon, avocado, and a fried egg. We doubt you’ll miss the lanes of yore one bit. Unless, that is, you have a thing for comb-overs. Lucky Strike Lanes, 1336 Chestnut Street (215-545-2471 or bowlluckystrike.com).

properties.name: Philadelphia Glass Works
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor  908a North Third Street, Philadelphia, PA(from Daily Candy) August 1, 2006 Glass Action You’ve got lots of artistic talent. Too bad you can’t act on it. Your watercolor self-portrait looked like Nancy Reagan in a party hat. One word: ouch. (Okay, another: ick.) Time to jump-start the creative process with a class at Philadelphia Glass Works in Northern Liberties. The three-day Introduction to Lampworking course teaches the untrained (yet creatively inclined) basic glassblowing. The next session starts next week, so book soon. You’ll learn how to use a torch to turn glass rods into decorative marbles. Should you discover a talent for the blowing arts, you can sign up for an intermediate class in the fall. For advance inspiration, stop by the gallery Saturday: There’s a sale on all new artists’ work. Because your browsing, appreciating, and shopping talents, on the other hand, are utterly unrivaled. Philadelphia Glass Works, 908a North Third Street (215-627-3655 or phillyglassworks.com). Introduction to Lampworking starts August 8.

properties.name: Philly Mini Golf
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor   Sixth and Race sts, Philadelphia, PA(from City Paper) August 10-16, 2006 Naked City Philly, to a Tee The giant challenges of creating a miniature, puttable Philadelphia. by Carolyn Wyman The documents and buildings relating to our country\'s founding are important. But they can be boring. Hence last year\'s creation of Once Upon a Nation, a year-old initiative of the nonprofit Historic Philadelphia, Inc., designed to make our city\'s history more relevant and fun. Once Upon a Nation deals primarily in tours and storytelling, but now they also do miniature golf. And what\'s more fun than miniature golf? Open until 9 p.m., a new Philly-themed mini golf course, and its companion Franklin Square carousel and playgrounds, helps meet Once Upon a Nation\'s other goal of creating more things for tourists to do at night, when those boring buildings and museums are closed. Three years in the making, the 18-hole course includes interactive reproductions of the Love sculpture, Benjamin Franklin Bridge and the Chinese Friendship Gate. On the eve of Franklin Square kiddyland\'s opening we spoke with Ruth Rosenquist of Studio Productions in Tempe, Ariz., the company charged with transforming Philadelphia icons into playable pop art. STONE FREE: There are no cobblestones in play on the Elfreth\'s Alley hole. STONE FREE: There are no cobblestones in play on the Elfreth\'s Alley hole. : Michael T. Regan City Paper: How did you decide on these particular buildings and subjects? Were there things that didn\'t make the final cut? Ruth Rosenquist: We designed the course with Castle Golf in Mesa [Ariz.] and Once Upon a Nation. A lot of ideas got thrown around and it was a group decision which ones to keep and which ones we weren\'t able to use. I know there was talk about the Franklin Institute\'s heart and a Philly food hole with a soft pretzel loop-de-loop. That would have definitely been a different style than the world-class, museum-quality realistic representations we\'re known for. But with most [of the cuts] it came down to budget and space and time. CP: The Philadelphia sports hole is a par 3. Given our sports teams\' records, wouldn\'t it have been more realistic to make that hole impossible to do in the 6-stroke limit? RR: Since Philadelphia is home to the great underdog story of Rocky , the course designers felt a par 3 was warranted. There isalways reason for hope in the world of sports! CP: Why didn\'t you put the cobblestones in the putting area of the Elfreth\'s Alley hole as well as on the sides? RR: We talked about it. But we were worried about people tripping and falling. We also worried about what it would do to wheelchair access. [The course is wheelchair accessible.] CP: What are the most challenging holes? RR: I think the Benjamin Franklin Bridge is a lot of fun and more interesting than the typical two- or three-part hole. There\'s only about an 8-inch height clearance on the bridge opening. If you don\'t make it you drop in the Delaware. CP: Any insider tips? RR: My colleagues at Castle Golf, the Arizona company that designed the play of the course, call the Ben Franklin Bridge hole a touch shot. The turf on the bridge is shorter, which makes the ball roll more easily than on the other turf surfaces. Be sure to hitthe ball with enough force to get it over the high point on the bridge\'s arch, or it will roll back, costing you a stroke. CP: Which holes were the most challenging to design? RR: The Museum of Art with the Rocky steps. The original design had the ball dropping down the stairs, which is the more typical way to deal with stairs in mini golf. There is a danger in putting up — the ball can become a boomerang. [But when Once Upon a Nation requested that the balls had to go up the stairs like Rocky] we were able to come up with a compromise that lowered the angle of the putt that didn\'t take too much away from the grandeur of the stairs. CP: Do you think it\'s a good course? RR: It\'s one of the most interesting courses I\'ve ever seen. I love the way it blends the educational with the historical. I know a lot of players will be attracted by the bells and whistles — like how the Liberty Bell rings when you putt into it and the snippets of songs that play on the Sound of Philadelphia and Rocky holes. The water also adds excitement. [In the Benjamin Franklin Bridge hole, the Delaware River is a water hazard, but on the Boathouse Row hole putting into the Schuylkill River spillway is the best way to get to the hole.] I also think the nighttime lighting on Boathouse Row and the Ben Franklin Bridge is really neat. CP: Are you embarrassed or proud to say you help make mini golf courses? RR: Proud, absolutely. Especially with this project. It tapped the creative juices of our staff in a way that few other jobs have. To have this located right in the heart of the historic district the way it is, we feel like we\'re playing a part in the city\'s history. daily through Sept. 4, 10 a.m.-9 p.m. (last tee time at 8:15 p.m.), weekends from Sept. 5-Oct. 31, -, Franklin Square, Sixth and Race sts., 215-629-4026, www.onceuponanation.com.

properties.name: Philly Roller Girls, Millennium Skate World
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor  1900 Carman Street, Camden, NJ(from Daily Candy) June 2, 2006 Roll Out Remember Xanadu? The movie in which Olivia Newton-John inspires Gene Kelly and some dude to build a roller disco where everyone’s dreams come true? That was totally based on a true story. Okay, maybe not. But fast-forward to this Sunday night, and some roller-rink wishes just might become reality. That’s when the spanking-new members of the Heavy Metal Hookers take on the Philthy Britches in the ongoing battle of the Philly Roller Girls. The league of all-girl roller derbyists was born of whatever bizarre ideas the ’80s bequeathed us about fantasy and roller skating — and it’s pure badass entertainment. After a musical opening act, the girls put on their skates, tackle each other, throw elbows, and stem bleeding noses. And they look totally sexy doing so, especially in the military-inspired uniforms Liz Truong designed for the Britches. Some audience involvement is involved, but don’t worry: There’s only a slight chance it’ll include dodging a machete. So get out there. This is a place where time stops, the magic never ends, and it’s all in good fun. At least until someone loses an eye. Philly Roller Girls, Millennium Skate World, 1900 Carman Street, Camden, N.J. (856-757-9460 or phillyrollergirls.com). Bout is Sunday, 5:30 p.m.

properties.name: Pinball Hall of Fame
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor3330 E. Tropicana Ave., Las Vegas, NVEast from the Strip, NW corner of Tropicana and Pecos, in the strip mall with Tropicana Cinemas. Between the comic book shop and Putters Bar. Open: Su-Th 11 am-11 pm, F-Sa 11 am-Midnight. Las Vegas, Nevada - Pinball Hall of Fame A non-profit operation with over 120 pinball machines and vintage arcade games, going back as far as 1949. The place has a "rec room" atmosphere but is HUGE (4,500 sq ft)! All the games are playable and fully restored. All quarters, no tokens. Any excess funds from the non-profit operation are donated to the Salvation Army. Includes several rare machines like Impacto (from Spain, only two known to exist), Black Gold (only one known to exist), and Pinball Circus (prototype only). [Steven F. Scharff, 03/05/2007] Las Vegas, Nevada - Pinball Hall of Fame Vegas resident Tim Arnold has been collecting vintage pinball machines for years, in hopes of eventually creating a museum. Since 2006, the Pinball Hall of Fame is the first step in creating that museum. Housed in a strip mall off the strip, the Hall of Fame has a small part of Tim\'s collection available for play at their original prices. [Robert, 02/18/2006]

properties.name: Rarebreed
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor  530 South 15th Street, Philadelphia, PA(From Daily Candy) June 14, 2006 Spray of Light These days, seems like anyone with a Sharpie and a stack of stickers can claim to be a street artist. What’s become of the old-school aerosol artist (and we don’t mean your tanning lady) who braved building tops and overpasses with backpacks full of paint cans and a fanatical assortment of spray caps? They’re at graffiti mecca Rarebreed, opening its new music/paint/T-shirt boutique off South Street this Saturday. Stop by and snag some tees by Plan and spray paint, and pick from Rarebreed’s selection of records and CDs to create a soundtrack for your urban art extravaganza. The cleaner, whiter, brighter walls also double as an art gallery; the opening show, up through July 10, features the work of Philly’s own A.I.D.S. (And It Don’t Stop) crew. So anyone concerned that old-style street art was a thing of the past can rest assured … The writing is definitely on the wall. Rarebreed, 530 South 15th Street (215-280-5599 or rarebreed215.com).

properties.name: Rescue Rittenhouse Spa Lounge
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor  255 South 17th Street, Philadelphia, PA(from Daily Candy) August 3, 2006 CleanseCrafters So your idea of taking care of yourself is ordering Diet Coke with your Big Mac and super-size fries. And your definition of exercise is a lively trot from one bar to the next. It’s not like the damage is irreversible. Especially if you book yourself into Rescue Rittenhouse Spa Lounge for their Ultimate Rescue Detox. You’ll start with a full-body sugar scrub, which sloughs away dead skin. Next, you’ll be treated to subdermal massage, which breaks down cellulite with suction and infrared light. Finally comes the detoxifying algae wrap. After smearing warm sea mud onto your body, they wrap you in a Mylar sheet and blankets to draw impurities to the surface (making them easier to flush out). While mummified, you’ll get a ten-minute facial massage using restorative oils. After which you’ll be shown to the shower to rinse off the green stuff. Afterward, hit up Rescue’s tea bar for an invigorating Elixir Tonic. That should keep you out of the local tavern for at least the next few minutes. Available at Rescue Rittenhouse Spa Lounge, 255 South 17th Street, mezzanine level (215-772-2766 or rescuerittenhousespa.com).

properties.name: Sugarcube
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor 48 South 3rd Street, Philadelphia, PA(from Daily Candy) August 7, 2006 Arrrr Rated Piracy has its good side (Johnny Depp movies) and its bad (bootleg copies of Johnny Depp movies). Either way, it’s a hot topic. Want in on the fun? It’s too steamy for those bodices Keira wears, but Artemisia jewelry will definitely help you get in the booty-hoarding spirit. Designer Marisa Lombardo collects charming items from all over the world — turn-of-the-century perfume vials, antique watches, military medals — and embellishes them (with, say, an offset charm or a hanging bell) to create pieces that look borrowed from the set of a swashbuckling blockbuster. And because they’re made of authentic relics, the treasures are a good investment for your hard-earned doubloons. As for how fellow pirates will react to your new loot? It’s sure to shiver their timbers. Available at Sugarcube, 48 South 3rd Street (215-238-0825).

properties.name: The Apothecary Garden
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor8640 Germantown Avenue, Philadelphia, PA(From Daily Candy) August 17, 2006 Witch Doctor Depending on what time of the day (or month) it is — and whether you’ve had your morning coffee — your mood ranges from totally calm to stark raving nutcase. When the latter occurs, wouldn’t it be nice to have an herbal remedy to cure what ails you? (One, that is, that’s legal?) Take your frazzled nerves, PMS, anxiety, and general battiness to The Apothecary Garden. There, you’ll consult with someone who won’t give you some scary diagnosis but will give you a soothing herbal tincture that you can mix with tea, water, or take alone. You can also get custom-blended teas based on your symptoms. If you’re blessedly symptom free (liar), just stop by the quaint Chestnut Hill shop for Bee House teapots, Octavia teas, and Sensuous Beauty balms and lotions. You’ll be riding the mellow train all day. Which is way, way better than the rollercoaster you’re on now. The Apothecary Garden, 8640a Germantown Avenue, Chestnut Hill (215-247-2110).

properties.name: The Shiatsu Studio
properties.description: Posted by Shannonor 2001 Frankford Avenue, Philadelphia, PA(from Daily Candy) July 27, 2006 There’s the Rub You’ve got a permanent crick in your shoulder, a chronically seized up lower back, and zero ability to turn your head to the left. Sure, things could get worse. Buy why wait till then to call Debi Phillpotts, shiatsu master? The petite stylist/massage therapist works out of a small studio above the Rocket Cat Cafe, and she can free you from that prison of body aches and pain. She practices five-element shiatsu, focusing on acupressure and breathing, which will restore a full range of motion to your 2,000 parts by freeing trapped energy that causes pain. After your session, you’ll feel like a bowl of jelly. And without all the ache, you’ll find moving around to be a far less harrowing experience. For one thing, you’ll be able to look both ways before crossing the street. The Shiatsu Studio, 2001 Frankford Avenue, enter through Rocket Cat Cafe (215-668-4076).
